Anyway, much more Computex coverage to come so stay tuned.

comments.text:
@BrawndoQC  When a serious hardware review outlet test a high end GPU at 1080p, they're actually testing the maximum performance the CPU can achieve. That's a CPU test, not a GPU test. If you want to test a GPU, you'd normally want to stress it at 4K resolution with the highest quality settings possible, no upscaling or any AI enhancement/motion smoothing technology. Usually, as long as you're testing a GPU with a modern, recent CPU, it doesn't have to be a 9950X3D or any future top-of-the-line CPU if you're testing at 4K resolution.

Testing a GPU at 1440p is not mandatory to see how powerful it is and understand its capabilities, although it's always a nice addition to the overall GPU review.

I want to see the 9060 16gb.  $350 is not bad and if it can match the 5060Ti 16gb (which you only seem to be able to get in systems) then I would call it the winner.

I think Nvidia is actually loosing this round.  The 5090 is fast, but other than that the 9070 is pretty good.  I kept hearing the rumors last year that the 5000 series was going to a beast and the R9000 series was going to be kind of a letdown.  So far it looks that AMD is far more of a competitor. comments.author: @SonNeturo

comments.text: I don't disagree with you. You made your logic clear. Our conclusions are equivalent, it's just that we had a different starting point for them. You think it's the companies that set the high expectations by grouping improvemental changes into generations, while I think it's the gamers who always have high expectations. Obviously both sides are at fault for the disconnect, but even if the companies were to correct course, and start naming their products as refreshes or go with the Pro versioning scheme, or what have you, gamers would be angry one way or another, because in their mind if the change isn't substantial, then the product should not exist, which is completely bizarre. It's just peak consumerism that I see everywhere, both hardware and software, from technology to utility.
comments.author: @RawbLV

comments.text: @RawbLV  I think gamers are angry because they are being sold a lie. I'm not really one to buy the latest thing all the time. I like to save money where I can. I have a 7 year old samsung phone and my computer is pretty much a frankenstein of bits and pieces I have bought on sale. When you are told that the 5070 is going to give you better performance then the highest tier of the past generation then there is no disconnect there, the expectations are set. If he had come out and just said here we have new chipsets and we also are bringing in ddr7 and better bandwidth then I doin't think anyone goes up in arms. It certainly won't please everyone and gamers will still be and also just let people review your products without the crazy t&cs. It's just a straight misleading. I'm not saying that gamers aren't at fault here either for when there expectations are super high but when you are told that it's kind of hard to then walk that back, especially when you are now paying off reviewers to cover your back. comments.text:
See, you understand it, you don't have to upgrade every year. But if you finally decided to, would you wait years just for the next generation of product to come out? Of course not. It's not consumerism to want an intermediate product version. But gamers think that every iteration is a scam.
And talking about memory, they did hate DDR5 when it came out, because it was expensive at the time and in their minds pointless and needless because everything was centered around DDR4. Then when the prices tipped in favor of DDR5, suddenly everything calmed down.
There are videos about this but I'm not sure how they're titled. I remember there was one tower case review of an average case with an average price, and it was unusual for that high profile YouTube channel to review a case where there is nothing to say about the thing really, but the entire video was centered about buyer's expectations, and how people were wanting a lower price tag on cases like these. The reviewer used the case to prove how it was built better and had more features: from the quality of metal stamping to paint, from mounting points to cable management options, and so on. Basically the cases of today are superior in every way compared to old cases, and adjusted for inflation, they barely cost more, but that's not good enough apparently.
So no; even if there was no marketing and everything was sold as is, you would not please the gamer, they want tomorrow's tech for yesterday prices.

comments.text:
At this point after seeing so many generations of GPUs between the ##60 and ##70 classes in a personal collection, backed with data from third parties, I would expect a consistent 18-22% generational improvement but Nvidia seems to want to bury that precedented expectation. The first exceptions rolling in around the 10## and 20## series where the gains where great! 

I don't know what happened over at Nvidia to convert them to darth Ngreedia but they cashed in (trashed out?) a lot of good will and pushed RTX real hard and the core performance gains have suffered greatly since. They have created their own marketing mess with the quarter and half tiers that are the "Ti" and "Super" sub series and they aren't much better than their main tiers. 

So, at this ranty point I would expect a 5060 to have at least 12GB of RAM and somewhere between 20%-32% better performance than a 3060 TI to be justifiable as an upgrade even with the diminishing gains we have had recently, otherwise I believe this should be classed more like a 3050/3050 Ti.

Anyway, I hate that I feel I should be ranting about this but I am still salty about how much I overpaid for a the only option which was a 3060 Ti at the time and there was no way I was paying $1600 for a 6900XT which was literally the only other card available in the store at the time after my old card died. It just just cost so much to play some of the same games with friends today when the options are so limited to the choices of a GlaDOS cake bake sale.

comments.text:
It's true that 12GB would be the ideal choice — and most people agree on that. However, even 10GB would be sufficient in many cases, as games at 1080p or 1440p often only slightly exceed 8–8.5GB of VRAM usage. Additionally, the operating system and background applications consume VRAM as well. Tools such as MSI Afterburner, Discord, Steam, iCUE, and other overlays contribute to this. For instance, MSI Afterburner alone can take up around 100MB. That's what we call allocated memory. 

I have an RTX 4070 Ti Super with 16GB, of course, and I often see games that barely go over 8GB. A card like the 3080 will handle things better — not just because of its faster chip (even though it’s two generations older), but mainly because those 10GB of VRAM really make a difference.

In my case, Windows 11 and other applications (Steam, Discord, iCUE, Chrome with YouTube) use up around 1500MB of VRAM on their own.

comments.text:
For anyone wondering about pushback against Nvidia’s insistence on MFG 4X, it’s because the feature is mostly marketing fluff on low end systems.  The latency is too high and introduces too much artifacting and smearing.

You really want a 5080/5090 before fake frames feel good due to low latency and high native frame rate.  The more real frames you have, the better your fake frame experience will be, and the better your mouse movement and latency experience.

5060/5070 4X MFG gives a high technical frame rate, but it’s incredibly dishonest.  Nvidia is trying to muscle reviewers with fake news.

It's not a bad card for a 4060 refresh; more features and more performance for a price that conforms to the current pricing scheme.

Either way you look at it we have a new budget 1080p gaming card and that's exciting for those who are limited to integrated graphics and bare bones graphical settings.

comments.text: I can understand 8GB for this model as it is the bottom of the stack, what I think is unnecessarily spiteful is the 8x PCIe bus.  WHY?  Are they paying per-lane royalties to the PCIe consortium?  It's really a forced upsell for people who have old hardware, precisely the people who will be looking at this card in the first place.  Added to that that this is the only card in the range that will get a low profile option making it suitable to retrofit old SFFs, but due to the 8x bus won't be able to achieve it's true potential.   This is really scummy move from nGreedia, but how else is Jensen supposed to be able to afford a private island and join his other tech bro friends?

comments.text:
What boggles my mind is that this card isn’t even that bad. Nvidias heavy handed approach with reviewers was a massive blunder as the stats don’t lie. If they just let the dice fall as they should it would have gotten neutral reviews and recomendable for people on a budget coming from something like a 1660, 1060, etc. who were looking to stay at 1080p. Nvidias heavy handed approach means this card is now viewed unfavorably by the big reviewers even more leading to even more bad pr for Nvidia. 

This card honestly offers good value at msrp, I saw a good number of 5060s listed for sale at my local mc for 299. And the rest at 320 to 330 which really isn’t all that horrendous compared to cards like the 9070, 5070, and higher. 

Yeah, it should have 12gb of vram but that would undoubtedly make it more expensive. How much it would benefit gamers in the budget market is a toss up tbh. Some of the gains this card makes while still only having 8gb of VRAM is impressive. 

I wouldn’t buy one because my budget allows for more but this card will sell and those who know what they are getting into probably won’t be all that disappointed, especially if they get it at msrp.

The REAL price of the RTX-5060 is going to hit the streets between $360-$450 amount. Most likely it will be bought at USD $390, instead of the (already) overpriced $300 MSRP.

This isn't a bad card per se, just horrible pricing. This level of performance and VRAM really should be sold at $250 or below.

Historically speaking, the RTX-5060 should at a minimum be beating the old RTX-3080, instead here it is getting bested by the problematic RTX-3070. It looks like the RX-6800 and RX-6800XT have aged like fine wine, in comparison.

comments.text:
At the REAL price of USD $390, the Cost per Frame is $6.97 which slots it slightly better than the Intel B580 and slightly worse than the AMD RX-9070.

As expensive as the RTX-5060 is, it still runs similar to the 5060Ti but at a slight $50-$99 discount. The worst buy in the stack is the 8GB VRAM of the RTX-5060Ti. If the RTX-5060 should have been a $200 card, and the 5060Ti (8GB) had been a $250 card, and the true-5060Ti (16GB) at $300, all would have been fine. The Cost per Frame would have been: $3.57 and $4.03 and $4.23, all respectively. Making them good value.

I believe Nvidia made okay cards, then slapped an extra +40% price on them, before the market/retailers slapped another +40% price on top of that. It is simply bad enough to go up a skyscraper.

comments.text:
⁠​⁠​⁠​⁠ @bhuvandeep1219 It does matter that’s one of the reasons the 2080 Ti keeps up with a 3 newer generations (and architectures) card, the 2080 Ti was no slouch, a big 754mm2 die 4352 cuda cores, with 11GB of GDDR6 over a 352 bit bus gave us 616GB/s of bandwidth

The 5060 is a very small 181mm2 die (maybe NVIDIA should give us a bigger die for the money, the 3060 was 276mm2 and the 2060 445mm2) 3840 cuda cores, 8GB GDDR7 over a 128 bit bus give us 448GB/s 

Per chip GDDR7 is better than GDDR6 (the amount of chips determines how wide is the bus) but just so you know the 2080 Ti had 11 1GB chips and the 5060 has 4 of 2GB each, so it is impressive that it has the bandwidth it has over 128 bits.

So no matter how you look at it, even if per unit is better, they are giving us too little hardware for too much money, that’s why you have 7 year old GPUs more capable than a mid (or should I say low end) tier GPU.

Or NVIDIA gave in the past too much or is giving nowadays too little.

And considering the 5090 die is 750mm2 (and the 90 class is the only where they are giving proper amounts of hardware, not proper, more like the usual amount in his class) and the 2080 Ti 754mm2 I kinda suspect is the second, that they are giving us too little

BUUUT if you are planning to play new titles the Nvidia should straight up just have a better card for the mid range. Why buy new card to only be able to play on mid to low settings at 1080p....Or have to slap on frame gen and pray that the potential artifacts dont bother you. I wonder if PCIe 5.0 ×8 is cheaper to implement than 4.0 ×16, or if nVidia went with it just so they could put "PCIe 5.0" on the box.

I'm also baffled by nVidia's efforts to stymie day-1 independent reviews. The 5060's a mediocre generational uplift, especially given the higher TDP, but I was expecting something far worse. If performance was inconsistent (e.g. Intel Alchemist at launch) or outright terrible (e.g. RX 6500 XT), then nVidia's PR tactics would perhaps make sense. I can only surmise that their marketing department are all high on the fumes from melting 12VHPWR connectors.

comments.text:
@Sagedurk  Dont bother reasoning with them, its impossible. I DO have a 3090... a 4090, and got a 5090 (because i can and use for work.. found it at msrp soo.. yea) The 5090 is powerful and the only worth thing of the 50 series so for the ppl saying "you dont have..." i also work with the datacenter ai ones h200 and so on so in terms of "owning and having tested them" im covered.

Frame generation works by taking information of past frames and motion vectors among other things, this beats interpolation stuff that HOLDS frames in a queue, but its NOT giving extra performance, its just giving extra VISUAL smoothness in exchange for artifacts and ghosting. The MAIN and most important benefit of high framerates is NOT visual smoothness (movies arent laggy right?... yet they run at 24 fps, weird isnt it), the benefit is lower input latency. 

Frame gen INCREASES input latency slightly but if you run at 60 fps your frame to frame delay is like 16.3ms, you get 240 fps, your delay is just 4-ish ms (nice thats much better). if you turn your 60 fps to 240 with mfg, your input lag will remain in the best case at 16ms but prob go up. That effectively makes frame gen useless for anything below lets say.. 100 fps non competitive...... but if you're already at 100 fps on a slow paced game... why would u use it then.. to get extra visual smoothness on a 360hz display when playing things like hogwarts legacy at 100 fps... maaybe on that specific case?. 

Lets say they perfect frame gen and it doesnt create a single artifact, that's good, you'll be able to obtain better VISUAL smoothness.. but not better input lag (and thats WAY more important to the feeling of the game, like cmon pc ppl has been mocking consoles for that for decades). What wont happen is that fake frames reduce input lag (like real fps do), for that they would have to unequivocally predict the unpredictable movements of the player inputs... and i think its more realistic for nvidia to just get better raw fps than to give us a literal tiny time machine... like bruh i would asap try to recycle that predictive algos to play the stock market lmao. Its impossible, like the "negative latency" of some cloud gaming stuff. When a tech gimmick requires time travel to function i suggest calling it bs.

comments.text:
I have a 4k HDR 120hz HDTV I primarily use for all my gaming. I upgraded from a 3070 to the 9070XT and I'm feeling a bit of buyers remorse, mostly because of relatively slow adoption for FSR4. The FSR4 cards released about a month after DLSS4 went public, and while DLSS4 is already in practically every new release, FSR4 is still being left out of a ton of new releases. In fact, I've seen a few games have opted not to do FSR at all, like Clair Obscur which offers XESS instead, and I understand why when XESS looks better than FSR3 and the market share for FSR4 supported cards is still too low to make adding it a priority. But still, it's disappointing because the 2 games I've used FSR4 in (MHW and KDC2) both look great and allow me to keep higher settings and still leverage my high refresh rate display.

So far, the reality has been that in most games, my choice is native resolution on the 9070XT or DLSS4 balanced on the 3070, and I must say that as long as I choose settings that fit in the VRAM buffer, the experience is roughly comparable. Clair Obscur and FF7 Rebirth are probably the most egregious examples of this because the "medium" texture settings don't look that much different to my eye in either game.
comments.author: @Under_the_Iceberg

comments.text: The point I'm trying to make is that at least right this moment, I feel like I may have been just as well served by going for the 4060Ti 16GB, the exceptions would only be the handful of FSR4 enabled games, which, as of this moment, are only 2 games, and Doom The Dark Ages is on my short-list of games I intend to play that advertises FSR4 support although I hear that it doesn't actually have it yet either?

comments.text:
I want to throw this out there in a serious manner.

In light of EVERYTHING going on right now with NVidia and the media, props to you guys to actually take the time and test the card objectively.  NVidia might get mad you didn't test it with all MFG turned on, but you know what, too bad, we as customers are seeing the increased latency of MFG and saying no.

I think you represented the product in a pretty good light, the only thing I WOULD complain about in your review would be saying you might recommend this card at 12GB of VRAM.  I've been shouting for a while 12GB should be the bottom VRAM for lower stack cards, so I think this should get a solid recommend at 12GB VRAM.  I'm also on record saying 12GB VRAM is just barely going to be keeping up by 6K series, so I understand why you said maybe, but at this MSRP I think 12 would have been acceptable for the 5060.  6060, no.

Good work on letting your integrity shine through.

Maths - UK price of a 3050 on launch adjusted to today is £300. So this card is currently, at £270, priced about where Nvidia tried to sell a xx50-class GPU at in 2021. Which would make sense - in a normal universe, a 70-class GPU would be equivalent to a 60-class after one gen and a 50-class after two.

The market segment this thing is at is a 5050. This is a budget, teen's-first-build card. Likewise the 5060 Ti is about where a 3060 was sold MSRP and the 5070 is about where the 306i Ti was. It's shrinkflation.

comments.text:
Steve doing proctology on Nvidias 3060Ti and 5060 sponsored by MSI while Tim holds an MSI 5060...sexily. In a hotel room and on a buisness trip sponsored by MSI. It somehow fits the bizarre state of Nvidia in this generation. Meanwhile Nvidia has yet to deliver on raytracing in any meaningful way  7 years after launch. It still is the domain of high-end cards and in the realm of upscalers and fake frames. Shouldn't a 5060 by now at least be able to get 60 fps in CP2077 in 1080p at native resolution? And I think I do not have to explain, what native even means. RT still is a bust and if it is forced into a game, it simply locks out a big chunk of hardware configurations.
In 2025 it increasingly becomes obvious that it is much more important to program games so they degrade gracefully so they run at 40fps on a Steamdeck than the game having insane RT specs. It now is mid-May and the 9070XT still is 50 Eurobucks over MSRP and if price does not come down soon, I will also skip this hardware generation. The 9070XT is quite expensive at 690 Eurobucks and I would feel generous to pay even that. Not Nvidia goes only so far and I feel taken advantage of. My 5600X/6800XT is soon becoming the longest I have had a computer without upgrades.

comments.text: y'know, vram issues aside, this is actually a fairly good value card. 10-40 percent better than the previous 60 tier card in games that don't exceed the VRAM buffer, reasonable power draw, thermals presumably under control, same affordable price as last gen. If you were putting together a new parts system with an intent to upgrade it down the line, or dropping in a cheap new replacement for something like an rx580, this would actually be a pretty compelling card at MSRP. Some of the ray tracing results are even - dare I say it - pretty compelling, with strong enough performance in Cyberpunk and Dying Light to satisfy most visuals oriented players. All of this is to stress how absolutely ludicrous it is that nvidia tried so hard to bury this one. All they had to do was market it as a good budget upgrade for people on older cards or a capae entry point and they'd have a much more positive result than now.

comments.text:
Me being 0 of a tech expert... I still have ~opinions inspired by this video: (they were 2 initially but it`s more like 3, where one of them is sort of a question)
My First impression is that in a way you've said "Nvidia straight up doesn`t want poor customers and is delivering them to AMD on a plat." 
But here comes a question: "Why do you people keep insisting that more V ram would have done something for ~not so powerful in other parameters cards?" Sure it wouldn`t have crashed on higher resolutions, but larger textures even if fitted in the V ram still take more to be processed, which makes for less frames per second processed ~per second, which makes it about as meaningless to be done in a first place as it not running at all that way, while still adding costs for nothing practically... which is in any real world Dumb... and Nvidia might be many things but I don`t think on a first look dumb being actually one of them. 
3rd Thing is... There were no 3rd gen RTX (they technically are 2nd gen RTX, because first "new" thousand series are GTX... yada, yada, bla bla) cards in the Ray tracing On measurements because Samsung fabrics Ampere technology even if with higher RT core counts, being much older gen in fact are super slow with RT enabled and their results are abysmal? Or am I wrong... In which case practically the ability to put a tick in the RT Box on a whim and experience grief to oblivion a lot less than doing so on 3070 (for example) actually makes the same amount of V ram (but also a generation newer, even it... the V ram, even if with a lot slower bus), but with much newer RT cores  makes it in fact even for that a real improvement. Which makes me ask how actually really RTX the 3000 series were rather than very, very pumped GTX and imagine the 2000 series in that regard thou. What do RTX 3000 series Ray Trace at this point even? o_0
 To strip down the entire above statement (at least it`s 3rd part) 5060 is 3070 +/- but with actual gains on Ray Tracing technology which the entire card line is named after being RTX and what not... And sure it`s a tier lower... Thus the 5070 is (for those price ranges)  juicy straight up and let`s not lie to myself the 5070 Ti with it`s, super shouted out at this point, 16 gigs of V ram is my current ~goal. (is how high I can aim ~reasonably so). 
Another argument is that well you as a tech guru state "2nd hand market" as something safe, because you can practically tackle problems on your own... But Lower budget gamers also happen to be newer into PCs as a whole and some do not become adept in that ~ever (<<< looks at myself)... So practically if no such thing as 3060Ti exist as a "in stock" option or 3070. Practically for that price point... out of Nvidia product that is <the option>. You have that much money... you want Nvidia... this is the Nvidia Nvidia have made for you. You have that much money and don`t like what Nvidia have made for you... wait to see what AMD can give you for that money... if it suits you better... it suits you better, be happy with it. But beware of the RT tick box thou... It`s not intended for that price range anyway... but if you wanna see what it does I am assuming you will sustain less disappointment with one of the two options. That being said me being on a certain RTX... I don`t think I have yet installed and played... thus seen an RT able game... but that is just me... I am the opposite of online competitive... I am online loser :P. Benefiting of still getting to play a game with reasonable hardware demands(at this point), just not getting to actually win in it :P.

comments.text:
At this point I am pretty much done with all aspects. I'm running a 1650ti. It runs my stuff. I turn down the settings. I want to replace it. But the 'hardware channels', who should long ago have reverted back to budget builds and much more, and now eternally just stuck on hi end GPU, CPU, Mobos, extreme costs and blathering about 5% differences in spaces no one gives a crap, and if they do come out of the ivory tower the content and takes are still stuck there. If 2025 according to you, and others - is a time where you cannot live without more than 8GB of VRAM, how is it I'm living on half that, and its ok. 'You are not buying AAA games!'. If I am living in 5060 or 1650 land, I'm not buying £80 AAA idiocy, yes, how well spotted.

Not that I am going to invest further time, but the 'We don't think 8GB Vram is enough', and we're going to run this budget/midrange card at ULTRA everything and then cry endlessly as we did with the 4060. 
'Everyone will jump to AMD because of this!!'. 

Where you did things more wisely, you pulled nearly 500 FPS in counter strike on Medium. 0% lows 50FPS up on both last gen 8 and 16GB units. 
All of the hardware channels need to take a hard look at what they are doing, and the economic cycle the end users are both in and heading into.

comments.text:
I picked up a 4070 Super in October for £450. I knew the new cards were coming but had a gut feeling that after the launch of the 20 Series was bad, the 30 Series was bad and the 40 Series was bad, that the 50 Series was going to be at most a 1-10% increase for a price hike of 20%+, only for them to be immediately made redundant by a Ti/Super series releasing the following year in 2026. I've never felt more smart about a purchase. Not only did the price of my 4070 Super go from £450 to £600, but the 5070 is in many games slower than the 4070 Super while costing more at the same time.

I actually felt so strongly about this gut feeling that I advised my wife and friends to make the same purchase. We all ended up snagging 4070 Supers around October 2024. I feel sorry for the people who buy these 5060s and 5070s at launch. It genuinely feels like a scam. If Sony released a PS6 tomorrow and it was worse than your PS5, you'd have riots in the street - but in the PC market its just accepted at this point that Nvidia will try to trick you into buying a product that would've been mid range 5 years ago.

comments.text:
Can't wait to see how nVidia responds to these reviews.  They seem to be hell-bent on equating MFG with actual performance, just as they did with DLSS.  Unlike with DLSS, MFG only provides a "motion smoothing" effect, and doesn't make games render more quickly.  At some point, nVidia will have to admit this.  There's no amount of copium that can keep them going at this rate.

As it stands, this GPU appears to be no better than the one from two generations before it.  It's like that kid who pumps his arms four times faster than everyone else in a sprint, but his legs aren't moving any faster than anyone else's.  He's yelling "Look mom, I'm the Flash" while losing the race.

comments.text:
Hey, a bit of a niggle here, but something you really should correct as it's wrong across the video: percentages are relative, and can't simply be reversed. A GPU being, say, 27% faster than another doesn't mean the other is 27% slower - that means it's 22.3% slower. Percentages are always relative to the basis of comparison, so "27% faster" means 127% relative to something else's 100%, while "27% slower" would mean 73% relative to something else's 100%.

You do this consistently throughout this video (and no, I haven't done the math to see which is correct), saying the 5060 is X percent faster while the graph is labeled with the competitor being X percent slower.

Oh, and do you have any idea what's going on with Stalker at 1440p? At first I thought this was an 8GB VRAM thing, but then the RX 6600 and 6650 XT somehow escape the wood chipper there - but the 7600 also doesn't. Almost as if the newer GPUs enable some sort of feature that suddenly makes 8GB insufficient or something?

comments.text:
WARNING: If you watch this & buy a 5060 anyway, do not complain about future games pushing high end visual features or RT as the default. 

You are choosing to buy a low end GPU with only 8GB of VRAM. Devs are not targeting PS4 level specs anymore, and RT has been a thing since 2018.

PC gamers used to be excited about new features & new tech being pushed in games, but now they want every AAA game to still run maxed out on their 1660 or 2060. You're choosing to buy an 8GB card in 2025, probably 1.5 - 2 years away from PS6/next Xbox.

Do not whine when future games run poorly or don't run at all on your system.

comments.text:
it very likely or I should say it could very well be that it doesnt use 25% more power than the 4060. You cant just take TDP and think this is how much the card uses. 

MY 5090 has a TDP of 575w and you know how much it usually uses? before I did my undervolt and overclock, which saves me about 100watts for the same performance, it drew like 400-500w. Very rarely did it shoot close to the 575w in gaming workloads; only really happened in very few games and in benchmarks. (funnily enough POE 2 did draw a shitton of power for example) 
Now with ma UV/OC it usually uses around 300-400w. And I play in 4k on a 4k240hz OLED, so it is running as fast as possible; its also paired with a 9800x3D, so as little of a bottleneck as possible as well.

The 4060 usually uses like 100w (vs 115w TDP). The 5070 for example has a TDP of 250w but it usually sits around 200-220w tops. the 5060ti is usually drawing around 130-140w instead of its 180w TDP. The 5060 has a 145w TDP, its using very likely a very good chunk less than that. But dont get me wrong - its still trash and nobody should a new 8gb card. Especially not the kind of person who is shopping for a cheap low end product bc if youre doing that, you are very likely already now having loads of money to upgrade to a 6060 again in 2 yrs bc you got VRAM problems.

Huh, so about 15-22% faster per dollar than a $269 RX 7600 depending on the resolution, and about 3% faster to 12% slower than a $249 Arc B580 per dollar also depending on the resolution. Admittedly, the B580 doesn't really exist at that price, but depending on which baseline you use, based on its rasterization performance alone, the RTX 5060 is either fine enough or just completely dismal. All of that is before considering the 8GB VRAM buffer, though, and that's becoming a massive limitation very quickly.

... It's becoming very difficult to judge new GPUs, but I'd still say don't buy this one. It'll undoubtedly get worse with age.

comments.text: It doesn't have to be performance charts at all. It's one of the most advertised features of the 50 series. It's a regular part of the product they're reviewing. There are people who will buy this thing and based on these reviews they don't have a slightest clue how it performs with FG or MFG. Reviewers say they want to inform us to the best of their ability so we can make educated purchasing decisions but they're literally leaving out included feature for some reason? Would you like if a car reviewer didn't mention how good or bad a car's stereo or AC is? I don't understand this stubbornness. DF at least gets it. They don't defend MFG but they include a snippet of info about it which is how it's supposed to be. If you look at this situation with NVIDIA this way, you can perhaps start to understand why they become a bit hostile towards them. I don't know the full story but this is my take on it. comments.text:
@saphyre-l4w Because frame-gen isn't performance, that's really all there is to it. If somebody asks you about a car's engine performance, are you really going to give them stereo specs? We aren't interested in features in performance videos. Features should be something you see in a separate video. Nvidia is bent on touting frame-gen as performance and that's the problem everyone has with it. They made that infamous statement, "5070 with 4090 performance" which is just a blatant lie. 

Here's an example: 
You have a 5070 that runs a game at max settings and you're getting 30fps while the 4090 gets 120fps on the same settings. But we use the 5070's 4x frame gen to match the 4090's 120fps. At a glance it may look the same, until you start to get noticeable artifacting and you realize you're getting enormous input-delay on the 5070. Meanwhile, the 4090 has flawless picture with extremely responsive inputs. Nvidia will happily ignore those rather important details and insist that the 5070 performs at the level of a 4090. 

I'm a 5080 owner myself and while I do like the frame-gen feature, I would absolutely not use it to supplement natively low fps. I would turn down settings to reach something stable and then maybe turn on frame-gen.  It's a nice smoothing feature for if your fps is hovering in the mid 40s or higher and that's it.
comments.author: @Crabbattles

comments.text: @saphyre-l4w Also you should really watch Steve's review of the RTX 5070, he does a good job of explaining why MFG isn't actually a boost to performance.
comments.author: @dMb1790

comments.text: ​@saphyre-l4w It wouldn't matter if frame gen could get them 1000 fps because the frame genned frames aren't actually being rendered by the game and thus the game wont actually run any better regardless of how many multiples of fake frames there are. You cannot compare frame genned frames to actual frames rendered by the game. To test it the way Nvidia wants these reviewers to do it is straight up dishonest and simply trying to trick people that don't know any better into thinking these cards are better than they actually are. It's just a marketing gimmick.
comments.author: @FantomMisfit12

comments.text: ​ @Crabbattles I have a 9070xt but I have yet to find a scenario where frame gen is actually useful. Seems to me all it's really doing is artificially inflating the fps and making input lag worse. I'd rather have lower FPS and the game being responsive so I can actually try and dodge these attacks from Annihilation or insert boss you have trouble with (Remnant 2)
comments.author: @FantomMisfit12

comments.text: @FantomMisfit12  Input lag is relatively minimal if your native frames are already high to begin with. There's lots of videos that showcase this much better than I can explain it as well. The input delay you get from using frame-gen while natively at say like 50fps, is extremely minimal. Using frame-gen while natively at 20-30fps is going to be horrendous, unplayable. I won't say no to having more features, I do think Nvidia just needs to stop falsely advertising it as performance.
comments.author: @Crabbattles

Game definitely felt slower with it. I don't so much see smoothness so much as feel it and frame gen does not feel smooth to me

comments.text: ​ @Crabbattles  The car example is a weird one. A stereo in a car doesn't impact the speed of the car, but MFG does impact the fps which is the primary factor of judging playability of a game. Now the input delay and image quality being bad is definitely true, and that's exactly why it's necessary to show it in a benchmark/review video. If you are using a GPU, why would matter to you if the card is giving great fps with MFG or without it given other issues are manageable. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying giving 8GB Vram is fine with MFG because it's absolutely not, but if the feature directly impacts the perceived performance, then why to ignore it?
comments.author: @bhuvandeep1219

comments.text:
@bhuvandeep1219  Ahh see, in my car analogy, the PC is the car here and the GPU is the engine that drives it (the CPU is really what drives a PC but we're talking about gaming here). Anyways, putting aside odd analogies, there is a bigger issue. You and I disagree on the core of the matter. I don't in any shape or form agree that it impacts any sort of performance. If my native frames are too low, no amount of MFG is going to "fix" that. Hell, you somewhat say it yourself in fact here. "Perceived performance", not actual performance.

You have to consider why a lot of us like getting high fps to begin with, besides just being buttery smooth to look at. Higher frames usually equates to snappier responses from our own inputs. MFG does not achieve this whatsoever. If your GPU is only putting out 20fps natively, 4x frame gen-ing that to 80fps isn't going to fix it.

I have to have wallpaper engine or video playback enabled or the audio cuts out and pops. Also losing DLSS support as a 4k gamer sucks. Hopefully they address these issues. comments.text: lmfao these ppl dont even know about bitrate/bandwidth/ram buffer...they just thing 16gb means its a HOT ticket LMFAO and they wonder why the 5060ti exists at 16gb for 500-600$ USD or a 7600xt 16gb exists....anyone care to explain why/how that level of niche usecase even exists at 128 bit. You can clearly see the "8gb" 3070 carrying its weight over these newer cards bc of the bandwidth really. NV just didnt want to offer that level of "SPEED" with a newer gen node with more L cache....bc it would make too much sense. So instead they use the L2 cache to buff the 128 bit 4060ti variants...and as you can see in various benchmarks the 8gb 4060ti or 5060ti are matching the 16gb cards in 1440p....or titles like black ops or cs2....where bandwidth still comes into play on lower settings to push those frames.

comments.text:
@RobBCactive 
rx 7600 irredeemable garbage. essentially the rx 6650xt with a new coat of paint and a new name. RX 6600 was killer at sub 200$ prices while this thing floated around 300.
rx 7700xt's pricing just felt weird all around. The price drop to 350$ made it alright. But it spent 80% of its life being absolutely useless at 450.Then at 350$ it was just mid value. 
Rx 7800xt was just a Rx 7800 pretending to be an XT card. The reduced compute unit count compared to 6800xt  wiped out any perf gains that rdna 3 had. At some prices that they were charging... just spend extra for the GRE. 
7900xt was alright and decent enough at 650 at one time.
GRE was a decent deal at 550. 
7900XTX had zero place. At the prices it was asking for, I'd just gone for the nvidia card for CUDA/actual raytracing/something that isn't FSR 3. The AMD's classic strategy of nvidia but -100$ doesn't work when the card costs 1000$+ and that you're also missing a boat load of features. 

Oh not to mention the totally useless AI cores. No real uses. The general purpose cores would be faster for most tasks and its not like they were any use for upscaling. 

Oh and this is a chiplet generation, meaning high idle power draw. 

Compared to rx 6000 series where the rx 6800/6800xt and the 6600 were absolutely oppressive. 

RX 7000 series was pretty awful. But it looks like RX 9000 series is a return to form if they don't completely butcher the last half of their product stack
